div1.p: Ravenel offers his opinions about Gorgas.

div1.head: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 3, 1925
div1.opener:
BACTERIOLOGY AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI
COLUMBIA
August 3, 1925.
Col. J. R. Kean,
Army Medical Museum Library,
Seventh and B Streets, S. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I am very much obliged to you for your letter of July 30th
with enclosed editorial. I appreciate also what you have said concerning
the review of Gen. Gorgas' life. It needs a word of explanation.

When the book was sent to me I rather protested against a re-
view because I feel so strongly concerning certain matters in Gen. Gorgas'
career and knew that I could not honestly accept all that his wife would
say about him. However, in spite of the fact that the book contains a
number of things which I know to be untrue and makes claims for Gen. Gorgas
which you have so well shown to be untenable, I was agreeably disappoint-
ed in many ways, and must say I was much surprised to find that it ac-
knowledged his disbelief in the mosquito conveyance of yellow fever. I
therefore had less trouble in writing the review than I anticipated,
but submitted to some modifications on the advice of the Managing Editor.

My attitude in the matter is easily explained. I am an old stu-
dent of Sewanee, Tenn., at the time when Gen. Josiah Gorgas was Vice-Chan-
cellor. For one year I boarded in Gen. Gorgas' house and can never for-
get the motherly kindness shown to me by Mrs. Gorgas. I did not know
Gen. W. C. Gorgas until many years after, as he was older and had left
Sewanee, but when I met him, as I did a number of times, he was always the
courteous gentleman, always gave me messages from his mother, and, what
appealed to me perhaps even more than this, was his friendship for my
cousin, David Gaillard, and his concern over the fact that David's death
took place on leave and he (Gen. G.) was unable to pay his expense
at Johns Hopkins.

My kindly feeling to Gen. Gorgas was almost entirely lost during
the world war. I was thoroughly disgusted with the display of nepotism
and the lack of fair play to the officers of the army who deserved pro-
motion and recognition. Among these allow me to say that you are one, who
should have been promoted to a generalship. I had the honor and pleasure
of knowing Maj. Walter Reed. In fact he invited me to go with him to
the Philippine Islands as bacteriologist on an expedition which never ma-
terialized, and the object of which I do not now remember. I am a native
of South Carolina and yellow fever has been my bread and meat, so to speak,
from infancy, and as a result I am pretty well posted on the history of
the disease and the efforts made to discover its cause. I was, therefore,
aware of almost all that you say in your letter and in your editorial.
The only thing that I did not know was that Dr. C. A. L. Reed was sent to
the Canal Zone by Mr. Taft. I always thought the A. M. A. was responsible
for this.

As to Gen. Gorgas, “de mortuis nihil nisi bonum.” I will only
say that his most intimate friend never accused him of having much
brains. He went further and higher on less work than any man I have
ever known. From his official position in the Canal Zone he of course
deserves much of the credit for the accomplishments there, and I do not
grudge to him the honors he received, except the one which made him Surgeon
General, an office for which he was absolutely unfit in almost every way,
and especially from the fact that for ten or twelve years he had been
out of touch with the army and did not know the army personnel. I also had
the pleasure of knowing Surgeon General Torney intimately. In fact, he
was my student at the U. Pa. in bacteriology, and I realize the truth
of what you say concerning the preparation of the Medical Department for
the great war under him and his predecessor.

You will see from this long letter some of the preparation I
had for writing this review and understand the difficulties I was up
against and the reasons why I held myself in check instead of telling a
good deal that I know and would like to have made public.

If it is ever my good fortune to have a conversation with you
I will be glad to tell you a good many more things unless this letter
has already fatigued you.
With much respect and again thanking you for your letter, I am,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Mazyck P. Ravenel.
